questions.text: What is a tax-advantaged retirement account?
options: Accounts like 401(k) or IRA that offer tax benefits for retirement savings
A checking account with no fees
questions.explanation: Tax-advantaged accounts like 401(k), IRA, Roth IRA offer tax benefits. Traditional accounts give upfront tax deductions and tax-deferred growth. Roth accounts have no upfront deduction but offer tax-free withdrawals in retirement. These dramatically reduce lifetime tax burden.

Selling investments at a loss to offset capital gains and reduce taxable income
questions.explanation: Tax-loss harvesting involves selling investments that have lost value to offset capital gains from profitable investments. This reduces your overall tax liability. You can use up to $3,000 in losses to offset ordinary income annually, with excess losses carrying forward to future years.

questions.text: What is the difference between tax deduction and tax credit?
options: Deduction reduces taxable income; credit directly reduces tax owed dollar-for-dollar
Deductions are illegal, credits are legal
questions.explanation: Tax deductions reduce your taxable income (if you're in 25% bracket, $1,000 deduction saves $250). Tax credits reduce your tax bill dollar-for-dollar ($1,000 credit saves $1,000). Credits are more valuable than deductions of the same amount.

questions.text: What is the 'backdoor Roth IRA' strategy?
options: A legal method to contribute to Roth IRA by converting traditional IRA contributions when income limits prevent direct Roth contributions
questions.explanation: High earners often can't contribute directly to Roth IRAs due to income limits. The backdoor Roth involves making non-deductible traditional IRA contributions, then immediately converting to Roth IRA. This legal strategy allows high earners to benefit from Roth's tax-free growth.

questions.text: What is depreciation in tax strategy for property owners?
options: A non-cash deduction that reduces taxable income by spreading property cost over its useful life
questions.explanation: Depreciation allows property owners to deduct the cost of income-producing property over 27.5 years (residential) or 39 years (commercial). This creates a 'paper loss' that reduces taxable income without actual cash outflow, significantly lowering tax burden on rental income.
